recordings.loc: Skidaway Island, Chatham County, GA USA
recordings.rmk:
A particularly clear recording of the drumming sound on a living tree. I shortened the interval between events by about 1 minute for convenience.  

For those who care: Most of he processing on this file was done in Audacity, but because the frequency of the drumming sound is so low, I could not use a high pass filter, and noise reduction did not reduce the low-frequency background sufficiently. So, I turned to iZotope RX7 and its spectral de-noise tool.  Excellent results.

recordings.loc: Burma Drive, Nanaimo, British Columbia
recordings.rmk:
The recording was extracted from the last 6 minutes of a 59 minute video taken with my camera, a Panasonic FZ200, with an added external Sennheiser MKE 400 microphone set up on a tripod in the parking area of the entrance to Linley Valley (Coddle Lake) Park at the end of Burma Road in Nanaimo, BC. A PIWO nest that had been discovered nine days earlier on May 29 still had two nestlings. Adults returned to feed the nestlings roughly every hour. While waiting, the nestlings were generally quiet. The nest was about 5 meters up in a large snag about 1 meter from the top and about 10 meters from the parking area.

The recording starts with both nestlings sticking their heads out of the nest waiting. At 0:05 a male adult arrives at the nest. One nestlings starts begging while the other gives out a short adult-like call and gets the first meal, regurgitated by the adult, at 00:07. That nestling proceeds to disappear into the nest leaving the other nestling alone to beg to the adult. At 0:12 this second nestling gets its first meal. At 0:19 this nestling gets a second meal. After poking at the adult the nestling gets a third course at 0:33 and a fourth at 0:43. Subsequent attempts to poke the adult for more fail and the adult just hangs on the tree as if waiting for something for 4 more minutes during which time the nestling begs continuously. Finally, the adult leaves after nearly 5 minutes at the nest. A few seconds later at 5:33 a drumming sound is heard, presumably by the adult, and both nestling heads appear outside the nest. The first nestling makes a couple more adult like calls at 5:40 and the camera battery dies shortly thereafter ending the recording.

The recording will end up online eventually and I will provide a link here.

recordings.loc: Sardis, Panola County, Mississippi
recordings.rmk:
Individual flying in from the NE. Calling continually while flying. Then perched in the very top of a dead tree and began foraging by flaying bark. No vocalizations after perching on the tree, but other PIWO could be heard in the background.

#Habitat#
Boardwalk through Cypress/Tupelo Gum swamp. Initially thick Tupelo Gum stand and then opens up into a broad open, grassy swamp with some isolated trees.  

#Editing#
Edited in Adobe Audition. Butterworth high-pass filter, order 3, cutoff frequency 700 Hz

#Equipment#
Fostex FR-2 digital recorder with Sennheiser microphone and Telinga pro 22" parabolic reflector.

recordings.loc: Maple Leaf, Seattle, King County, Washington
recordings.rmk:
2 birds in this recording, one on a telephone pole, the louder of the two, and one in the distance who is both drumming and calling. The bird on the pole would drum, then stop and listen for the second bird. I've heard a single bird drumming for over a month at this location, but this was the first time I heard 2 interacting.  In the end the bird on the pole flew off in the direction of the second bird.
I condensed this recording  (it was originally over 11 minutes long) and amplified it a bit so the second bird was easier to hear.

recordings.loc: Bow, Skagit County, Washington
recordings.rmk: this recording is about 10 minutes prior to locating the species.  I was approximately 75 yards away and able to capture the loud jack hammer like drumming on a Samsung Note 3 Android.  In order to appreciate the drumming, the volume had to be increased in Adobe Audition which also increased the hiss.  A proper noise profile was captured and only the hiss mitigated so that the drumming is more appreciable.  In the background is a chestnut-backed chickadee.

recordings.loc: Bow, Skagit County, Washington
recordings.file-name: XC314295-Pileated Woodpecker-Samish Island at close range.mp3
recordings.rmk:
Recorded at very close range near the point of Samish Island, Washington at 7:54pm on a Samsung Note 3 android.
Initially heard the drumming from a distance as it reverberated through the forest.  Ultimately tracked down the Pileated.  The distance was approximately 20 feet from the dead tree and the Pileated Woodpecker was approximately 30 feet high.  Photos were also obtained.  You can hear a small propeller plane in the background.  Cleanup in Adobe Audition.

Witty's Lagoon, Metchosin, Vancouver Island, BC
Marlborough, Middlesex, Massachusetts
recordings.rmk: Odd goose-sounding calls from a very active and vocal pair of Pileated Woodpeckers.  During the 15 minute viewing period, this male/female pair acted bonded and called back and forth to each other repeatedly.  There was some territorial drumming, the loud territorial call, flight calls, and finally this odd sound.  The birds were right above me, but perhaps 20-30 meters up a tall snag, when they gave this call.  This may be the analog of the Northern Flicker's "weeka" call.  I cannot find too many examples of this call recorded.
